contents:
The Affordable Art Fair is in town, showcasing works from more than 1,000 artists at Chelsea’s Metropolitan Pavilion. Pieces at mega fairs like Frieze and Art Basel come from art-world superstars and can fetch millions. Art at this New York fair, however, sells for a more manageable maximum of $10,000. We visited the Affordable Art Fair in its first hours to find our favorites.

At Your Service II by Anna Church; Colab Collective, New York City.



Silver spoons and gravy boats receive their due honor in New Zealand artist Anna Church’s At Your Service series. Church describes the work has “unapologetically nostalgic,” harking back to a time when casual wasn’t cool, and when even a nightcap warranted crystal. $875.

 

Untitled by Peter Barelkowski; Spence Gallery, Toronto, Canada.


We loved the simple story reflected in this piece: a loving couple sits peacefully, protecting their community as their winged bodies form a single heart. Polish-born Barelkoswki refuses to name any of his works, letting the viewer find his or her own narrative. $6,500.


Untitled by Jean-Paul Donadini; Galerie de Medicis, Paris.


The massive painting from Jean-Paul Donadini jumps off the canvas with with a paintbrush and ruffling curtain, resembling a half-finished Mondrian. Bold, strong lines coupled with the playful deconstructionism on the right make for an engaging piece that stopped us in our tracks. $10,000.


Coliseum by Guillaume Cornet; Decorazon Gallery, London and New York City.


Guillaume Cornet has made a name for himself with extremely detailed cityscapes loaded with funny and unusual stories. The combination of macro and micro scope unites places and people, which are “the things in life that inspire me most,” he says. Cornet uses traditional analogue sketching and printing techniques, making each one entirely unique. $4,500.


Flock by Alasdair Wallace; Rebecca Hossack Gallery, New York City.


This soothing painting from Scottish painter Alasdair Wallace is a surrealist update to historic vanitas paintingsâ€”popular in 17th century Netherlands and featuring heavy use of symbols. Here, Wallace depicts a diverse flock of birds complete with a fair share of symbolic surprises: birds with glasses, hidden hourglasses and keys. $10,000.
